markdown:
<title
    level="1"
    right="Weapon 0"
    pfs="Standard"
>
[Filcher's Fork](/Weapons.aspx?ID=407)
</title>

<traits>
<trait label="Uncommon" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=159" />
<trait label="Agile" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=170" />
<trait label="Backstabber" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=172" />
<trait label="Deadly d6" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=174" />
<trait label="Finesse" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=179" />
<trait label="Halfling" url="/Traits.aspx?ID=87" />
<trait label="Thrown 20 ft." url="/Traits.aspx?ID=195" />
</traits>

<column gap="tiny">

**Source** [Player Core](/Sources.aspx?ID=216) pg. 278 <sup>2.0</sup>

<row gap="medium">
**Price** 1 gp

**Damage** 1d4 P

**Bulk** L
</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Hands** 1

</row>

<row gap="medium">
**Type** Melee

**Category** Martial

**Group** [Spear](/WeaponGroups.aspx?ID=14)
</row>

</column>

---

This [halfling](/Ancestries.aspx?ID=5) weapon looks like a long, two-pronged fork and is used as both a weapon and a cooking implement.

<title level="2">Critical Specialization Effects</title>

**Source** [Core Rulebook](/Sources.aspx?ID=1) pg. 283 <sup>4.0</sup>

Certain feats, class features, weapon runes, and other effects can grant you additional benefits when you make a Strike with certain weapons and get a critical success. This is called a critical specialization effect. The exact effect depends on which weapon group your weapon belongs to, as listed below. You can always decide not to add the critical specialization effect of your weapon.

[Click here for the full rules on Critical Specialization Effects](/Rules.aspx?ID=235).

<document level="2" id="weapon-group-14" />
name: Filcher's Fork
